Award.AwardTitle: Multimedia Learning of Engineering Economics through Role Play Gaming on a Mobile Platform

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This project, led by Lamar University, is increasing the knowledge base in how people learn using mobile computing technology by investigating the use of mobile technologies in an Engineering Economics course. The mobile technology allows a ubiquitous learning environment suitable to student lifestyle constraints. Specifically the project is studying the effectiveness of mobile technology in promoting deep and lasting learning of content, practice, skills and attitudes. Expected results include more student engagement and better performance on in-class exams. Smart phone apps developed by the project include role-playing games that allow students to interact with the app or with fellow students. The project uses formative and summative assessment to continuously guide the researchers in assessing the results. This study has application in a number of STEM education areas and therefore will significantly improve STEM education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal is to evaluate the impact of how a smart phone app would promote the interest and enhance the learning experience with students who are enrolled in engineering economics by using multimedia and educational game elements. We have chosen engineering economics, which is a course where the time value of money is the core concept. It is perceived to be a challenging subject to students. The core idea is that smartphone apps can potentially help today’s students by providing ubiquitous access to multimedia learning materials along with more channels for interaction.

In addition to the game settings, the app includes many pedagogical features, such as, an e-book, a specialized calculator, interest table generation tool, and video lectures on demand.

The app has been in used in the classroom, it has been available for studying, solving home work assignments and during tests. In surveys, students report the convenience of the ubiquity of the app for their daily learning. Also, they were very satisfied with the help in the computation of complex formulas, facilitating the learning of the application, and not just the computation of problems.

The app was made available in the iOS and Android store, making them readily available for free for everyone - faculty, students and general public.

While students report the convenience of using technology, most of the surveyed students were taking courses in the traditional format. Most of them considered themselves early technology adopters adopters (just over 60% agreed or strongly agreed),  Most of them report enjoying  the use of technology (90%), and most of them believed that technology enhanced their learning (82%).

Students preferred the app content to be in sync to the specific course calendar for each pearid, so they can use it to plan a studying schedule and track their progress. That feature was included in the last release. The app is now customizable to include different topics at different periods, making it easy for faculty or students to prioritize in sequential modules the contents of the course.

We have addressed the challenges of having a communication device during the tests. Currently we request students to keep their phones in airplane mode. Enforcement to this rule is achieved by inspecting the connecitvity status of randomly selected students' phones at random times.

We achieved the objectives of developing an app, and assessing the convenience and impact for students learning. Most students reported satisfaction and interest in keeping the app as part of the learning tools. However, there was not sufficient statistical evidence of grades improvement just by means of using the during the course. We believe that the app made the course learning more effective for students who were prepared to pass the course. The grades statistics suggest that the factors affecting the grades are more complex than the contents of the course and the availability of learning tools.
